Award.AwardTitle: PEEPS - Program for Engineering Excellence for Partner Schools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project presents an institutional approach towards recruiting, retaining, and graduating engineering students from disadvantaged backgrounds. Targeted students come from high schools that have large percentages of students who qualify for the National School Lunch Program. Data suggests that these students are not only more likely to have low socioeconomic status, but also be first generation college students and/or underrepresented minorities (URM). Scholarships of up to $10,000 for four years are extended to engineering students with high financial need. The first cohort is expected to include six Mechanical Engineering (ME) students and the second cohort is a mix of six College of Engineering students starting the second year. A long-term benefit of the project is that is increasing the ability of the California Polytechnic State University to improve educational opportunities for disadvantaged students effectively and efficiently.

The technical merit of the project rests on research that has suggested that reasons for the lack of comparative success of disadvantaged students include feelings of isolation, lack of self-efficacy, financial pressures, and the lack of appropriate academic support. The project meets those identified needs, and the evaluation and assessment of the program measures the impact of the combined support mechanisms on the students' academic success. Specific features of the project's implementation include the formation of cohorts of student learning communities to support one another and create a sense of belonging and to build community. The cohorts also take several engineering support courses together, and are automatically enrolled in supplemental workshops in Science and Mathematics and the Engineering Success courses. The project removes obstacles and integrates several proven student success strategies to help students develop their personal academic and professional goals. Thus, project components not only include financial support, but also block scheduling of gateway engineering support courses with supplemental workshops, frequent advising, individualized coaching and mentoring of personal academic and professional goals, professional development opportunities, and STEM outreach activities. The proposed activities help strengthen student identities as an engineer increase self-efficacy. Assessment and evaluation of the project contributes to the knowledge of how engineering students succeed, and how the learning community model may be expanded to more students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the PEEPS program were both specific and broad. It was our intention to provide a full range of supports for a small cohort of engineering students from non-traditional backgrounds that would allow them to graduate. In addition, we hoped to influence the university to create a more supportive and welcoming environment for these students. We are consistently proud of the accomplishments in both these areas. Specifically, of the 14 individuals who were in the two cohorts, nine graduated (one went on to get an MS), two are very close to graduating with both a BS and MS in engineering, one is still completing his engineering degree, and two left the university. We have celebrated these individual successes and continue to connect with them even after graduation. 

In the area of Intellection Merit, we have produced ten peer reviewed conference papers. In addition, our thinking has evolved to include the following orientations: 

  1. The effort put into supporting individual students, while good and necessary, is not sufficient to overcome institutional and systemic biases that were originally designed for white students from a privileged background. The graduation rates of these cohorts were statistically insignificantly different than URMs in the College of Engineering for those same years. PEEPS had a 6 year graduation rate of 64%, while URM in the College of Engineering at Cal Poly, SLO had a 71% rate. This realization caused the team to focus further on institutional transformation using Critical Race Theory and Asset based approaches. 
  2. We remained convinced that the cohort model is vital to the success for students from non-traditional backgrounds. The connections the student have with each other enhance resilience that is necessary to navigate the predominately white university. 
  3. Individual support for students is not enough to transform the institution. Deeper and systematic changes are necessary for lasting transformation. For instance, when special requests were made to support the cohort of student, personal relationships were the only way to accomplish this. This is not a sustainable way to transform the system.
  4. When we initiated the grant, most of us in Engineering had a deficit model for students from under resourced backgrounds. Through the research and relationship with the PEEPS cohort students, we could see the assets the students possess, and have shifted to asset-based approaches. This now greatly informs our current work and future research, in addition to changing all the conversations we participate in.

In the area of broader impact, we have influenced the institution and beyond through this project. Specific accomplishments are listed below. 

  1. PEEPS influenced a large university program called CP Scholars in that many of the supports and cohort building processes were added to this ongoing institutional effort. 
  2. Many of the support activities developed in PEEPS were added to Engineering Student Services in the College of Engineering. For instance, transfers students now have a monthly gathering called ?Food for thought? that grew directly from the acknowledgement of the usefulness of a support system for students from non-traditional backgrounds. 
  3. PEEPS included the design of two courses (one for freshmen and one for juniors). These were taught for several years, and now the freshmen course is taught within the university CP Scholars program and the junior level course has expanded to support all transfer students.
  4. Because we connected with the PEEPS students more deeply and consistently, we were able to see the need for university to support students in both providing for basic needs (food and shelter) and mental health. Individuals in the PEEPS support team have participated in the university?s development in both these areas. 
  5. The two students who left Cal Poly had very good reason for leaving. We never felt this transition from Cal Poly was a failure. We have worked to expand the goals of future work to include these valid decisions by students. These conversations are now occurring on campus.
  6. Initiation of AmeriCorps volunteers to support the project grew to include multiple AmeriCorps volunteers on campus in a variety of units. The AmeriCorps Cal Poly connection continues to this day. 
  7. Several in the support team have furthered the work in a variety of concrete ways: 1) Two of the Co-PI?s have an NSF S-STEM grant supporting students at community colleges and Cal Poly (ENGAGE) with elements developed in PEEPS. 2) The initial PI moved to WPI where she has initiated several programs to support students similar to PEEPS. She also participated in a successful S-STEM grant at that University. 3) One of the active staff members moved to CSUSM, where she worked to develope support systems for students that mimicked some of the activities in PEEPS. 

We are very happy with the work we accomplished and feel grateful for the support of NSF in these endeavors.
